properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Kenley.

  • An evacuation warning remains current. It is still not safe to return.
  • Floodwaters are continuing to rise along the Murray River downstream of Wakool Junction. 
  • Major flooding is occurring at Kenley, with floodwater continuing to rise to its peak slowly over the coming week. 
  • Hazards exist in and around the Kenley area. We strongly advise those planning to visit the area to make alternative arrangements.
It is not safe for people to return to Kenley. If you have not evacuated, leaving now is still the safest option.
Travel to a safe location such as:
  • Family or friendsâ€™ homes located in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • The Emergency Relief Centre at The Stadium (Basketball Centre), 15 Gray Street, Swan Hill. Phone: 0447 094 347
When you leave:
  • The safest route to evacuate is via Coghill Road to Murray Valley Highway.
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone and medications.
If you have already evacuated:
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at a relief centre so that your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
If you stay: 
  • If you choose to stay, emergency services may not be able to help you. 
  • Stay inside and be aware of changing conditions. 
  • If floodwater comes inside, move to a higher point such as a kitchen bench or second story. 
  • Follow your emergency plan, if you have one. 
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation, if safe to do so. 
Impacts in your area:
  • Based on current predictions, it is possible that the levee in Kenley may overtop over the coming 2 to 3 days. 
  • Impact assessments are being undertaken in Kenley. These assessments will inform further predictions. 
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some areas. 
  • This flood may be similar to the 1956 flood event.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home.
  • Areas near the affected location may lose services including power, water, sewerage and phone coverage due to flooding.
  • Evacuating too late or choosing to remain in your home when recommended to evacuate is dangerous and may put your life at risk .
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 11/11/2022 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Murray River downstream Barham to Benjeroop
properties.webBody:
This Watch & Act is being issued for the Murray River downstream of Barham to Benjeroop.

Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray River and its tributaries.

  • The Murray River at Barham peaked at 6.21 metres on Wednesday 26 October and is currently at 6.14 metres and steady, with major flooding. The Murray River at Barham is likely to remain above the major flood level (6.10 metres) through to the end of the week.
Some properties remain isolated due to standing water across many areas. Aircraft (including drones) are being used to determine the extent of water inundation across the area. Emergency services personnel are assessing impacts on affected properties caused by overtopping and levee breeches. 

Emergency services are assessing and reinforcing existing levees as required, protecting isolated assets and providing relief to local communities and primary producers. The evaluation of potential impacts on critical infrastructure and townships remains a focus.

The latest community newsletter dated Wednesday 9 November 2022 is available here: Community Newsletter
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes. 
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting http://www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/ 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - do not drive through floodwater.
  • Stay away from damaged and flooded buildings, fallen or damaged trees and powerlines, and damaged roads until authorities advise they are safe.
Never allow children to play in or near floodwater!
  • Flooded rivers and creeks can contain toxic chemicals such as petrol, oil, animal or human waste, pesticides and runoff from roads, paddocks, drains and even sewage overflows (poo and wee and anything else that is flushed down the toilet). 
  • Raw sewage and floodwater can contain bacteria and viruses like E Coli, Giardia and Hepatitis A. Swallowing even a small amount of this can make your children sick. Open cuts, grazes and wounds can easily become infected.
  • Barbed wire, rubbish, branches, broken glass, metal fragments and other loose items can all find their way into floodwater. These objects can cause a child to get tangled or severely injured. They could lose their footing and strain a muscle, roll an ankle or they could fall and be knocked unconscious.    

Floodwater is dangerous. Stay safe - never enter floodwater. 

If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Support for flood impacted farmers and producers:
  • Farmers who require support to prepare for flooding, who have been impacted by floods and require assistance or have urgent animal welfare needs, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
  • For further information on managing crops and livestock after a flood, including budget feed plans, and other support and assistance, visit agriculture.vic.gov.au
Impacts in your area:
  • High river levels may cause flooding in areas close to rivers and streams. 
  • Some agricultural land may be vulnerable to flooding. Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground. 
  • Local roads and bridges may be closed.
  • Breeches and overtopping of levees have occurred, leading to additional impacts particularly in Murrabit West and Benjeroop.
  • There is currently no access for 4WD vehicles between Murrabit West and Benjeroop due to water inundation along Murrabit West Road. 
  • Emergency Services are actively patrolling and monitoring the integrity of levees, roads and bridges while continuing work to reinforce control lines and sandbagging.
  • Coliban Water has advised that they are currently experiencing poor raw water quality in Cohuna, which is placing pressure on the Water Treatment Plant. For more: https://coliban.com.au/interruptions   
  • Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. For more information relevant to your area, please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria.
Murray River closure: 
The Murray River is closed to river craft downstream of Tocumwal Bridge to Robinvale.  People and boats are prohibited from entering the river between these locations. Any person on the Murray between these points are to leave the river.  This declaration applies to all residents on both sides of the border.  Neither NSW or Victorian users are permitted on the river at this time.   

Snakes:
  • There are a high number of snakes active in flooded areas.
  • Snakes may look for shelter and food in flooded areas. 
  • Be careful around houses, storage sheds and other buildings near floodwater.  
  • Call DELWP on 136 186 for advice on snake controllers in your area. 
  • If someone is bitten, call 000 immediately. 
Mosquito alert:
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. 
  • For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes) 
Infectious diseases: 
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases.  
  • There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness.   
  • Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected.  
  • Find out more, visit:  Better Health (Emergencies - floods) 
Mould: 
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. 
  • When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell.  
  • For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home) 
Flood-affected septic systems: 
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include: 
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked 
  • Tanks and sumps 
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework 
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
Blackwater event:  
Significant rainfall and flooding can cause water quality issues like low-oxygen (hypoxic) blackwater and blue green algae. High levels of organic matter have been washed into waterways and, combined with warm weather, can cause oxygen levels in the water to drop. This can harm or cause the death of fish and crayfish. River managers and scientists monitor rivers for water quality issues and work to reduce the impacts of a blackwater event where they can. Low levels of dissolved oxygen are recorded at several locations across northern Victoria and in the Murray River. The scale of the current flooding means water quality will not improve quickly. Any fish death event in Victoria should be reported to the EPA by calling 1300 372 842. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Barmah, Barmah East and Lower Moira. 

This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued at 3.52pm Tuesday 08/11/2022. 

  • Major Flooding is occurring along the Murray River at Barmah. The river level is currently at 7.09 meters and steady, above the major flood level of 7.00 meters
  • SES in conjunction with CMA estimate that as the river level falls to around 6.8 meters the water pressure on the levee bank will subside. At 6.8 meters the risk will reduce and pumping of water will no longer be required. 
  • Moderate flooding is currently occurring upstream of Barmah to Lake Hume.
  • Hume Dam is currently releasing 74,699 ML/D as at 3pm 9th November.

Rainfall is predicted later in the week. Please monitor all conditions-water levels may change as the result of rainfall. 

This message is for communities in Victoria. Flood impacts vary along the Murray River between NSW and Victoria. For information and warnings relevant to NSW, please check www.ses.nsw.gov.au. Always follow the instructions provided by your State's emergency services.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

The wet ground conditions have resulted in many trees falling without warning.  If it gets windy, trees will become more unstable and deadly.  Never park, take shelter or camp under a tree.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Be aware of the increased likelihood of trees falling due to the very wet ground, especially in windy conditions. Never shelter under trees.  
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/

If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.

If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.

If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.    
  • Check the Vic Traffic website (Vic traffic) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Flood levels may remain above floor level of a single-storey home.
  • Based on historic data, this flood has had a similar impact as the 1993 flood.
  • Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. For more information relevant to your area, please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
Community notification:

Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould)

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent More information on hoe to reduce your risk visit Better Health (Mosquitoes)

For information on how to prevent gastro visit Better Health (Gastro)

Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility.  Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases.

Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home.  Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas.   

The Picola to Barmah Road is now open, however shallow water may still cover some parts of the road. The Nathalia relief centre is still open at the Nathalia Community Centre, 42 Robinson St, Nathalia operating 10am - 2pm, for after hours phone 0419717147.

properties.location: Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte.

  • The Yarra River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 1 mm in the upper part of the catchment and about 2 mm in the lower part of the catchment since 09:00 AM Tuesday 08 November 2022. Rainfall totals of 1-5 mm with isolated amounts of 10-15 mm due to potential thunderstorm activities are forecast for the catchment for Wednesday 09 November 2022.

Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte
The level of the Yarra River at Yarra Glen is currently rising to its peak of around 4.5 metres, below the Moderate Flood Level (4.60 metres).

Minor flooding in the Yarra River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway including bicycle paths.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/11/2022 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch & Act is being issued for the Lower Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.

  • Flooding continues to occur in the Lower Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.
  • Releases from Kow Swamp into the Pyramid Creek have been reduced now that inflows to Kow Swamp have significantly decreased.
  • The peak of the Bullock Creek inflows and Kow Swamp releases are now downstream of the Milnes Bridge area, heading towards the Kerang-Koondrook Road.
  • This peak is staying around properties for up to three days.
  • Floodwaters may continue to impact properties along the Pyramid Creek from Kow Swamp to Kerang area.
  • Further rises are expected downstream from Milnes Bridge to Kerang over the next three to six days.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:
  • Farmers in low-lying areas should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Follow your emergency plan and locate your emergency kit, if you have one.
  • Drive slowly, obey all roadblocks and never drive through floodwaters. Check the https://traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/ website for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Stay away from damaged and flooded buildings, fallen or damaged trees and powerlines, and damaged roads until authorities advise they are safe.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • If you are camping close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move to higher ground, away from waterways.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Kerang-Murrabit Road is closed due to floodwater. 
  • Other local roads and bridges are closed due to flooding. 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • You may lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
Snakes:
  • There are a high number of snakes active in flooded areas.   
  • Snakes may look for shelter and food in flooded areas. Be careful around houses, storage sheds and other buildings near floodwater.   
  • Call DELWP on 136 186 for advice on snake controllers in your area. 
  • If someone is bitten, call 000 immediately. 
Mosquito alert
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes)
Infectious diseases:
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases. There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness. 
  • Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected.
  • Find out more  Better Health (Emergencies - floods)
Mould:
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. 
  • For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home)
Flood-affected septic systems:
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include:
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked
  • Tanks and sumps
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/11/2022 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Thomson River downstream of Wandocka.

MINOR FLOODING EASING AT SALE WHARF

The minor flood peak has passed Sale Wharf and river levels are likely to ease during Wednesday.

Showers and thunderstorms are forecast for overnight Thursday and Friday and renewed river level rises are possible from Friday morning. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.

Thomson River downstream of Wandocka:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Thomson River downstream of Wandocka.

The Thomson River at Sale Wharf peaked at 2.66 metres around 11:00 am Monday and is currently at 2.52 metres and falling slowly, with minor flooding. 
The Thomson River at Sale Wharf is likely to remain above the minor flood level (2.40 m) overnight Wednesday into Thursday. The river level may fall below the minor flood level (2.40 m) Thursday afternoon.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.

properties.text:
ADVICE - RIVERINE FLOOD - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Thomson River downstream of Wandocka
Issue Date: Wednesday 09 November 2022, 02:30 pm
Next Update: Friday 11 November 2022, 03:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/26475/moreinfo


This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Thomson River downstream of Wandocka.

MINOR FLOODING EASING AT SALE WHARF 

The minor flood peak has passed Sale Wharf and river levels are likely to ease during Wednesday. 

Showers and thunderstorms are forecast for overnight Thursday and Friday and renewed river level rises are possible from Friday morning. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary. 

Thomson River downstream of Wandocka: 
Minor flooding is occurring along the Thomson River downstream of Wandocka.

The Thomson River at Sale Wharf peaked at 2.66 metres around 11:00 am Monday and is currently at 2.52 metres and falling slowly, with minor flooding. 
The Thomson River at Sale Wharf is likely to remain above the minor flood level (2.40 m) overnight Wednesday into Thursday. The river level may fall below the minor flood level (2.40 m) Thursday afternoon.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Broken Creek at Walshs Bridge.

This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 12.28 , Monday 7 November


MINOR FLOODING TO CONTINUE AT WALSHS BRIDGE AND NATHALIA FOR THE NEXT FEW DAYS

Minor flooding is expected to continue along the Broken Creek between Walshs Bridge and Nathalia for the next few days.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Monday, no significant rainfall totals have been observed across the Broken Creek catchment. Showers and thunderstorms are forecast for Thursday and Friday.

Minor flooding is occurring along the Broken Creek. Minor flooding is expected to continue at Walsh Bridge for the next few days.

The Broken Creek at Nathalia is currently at 1.75 metres and falling slowly, with minor flooding. The Broken Creek at Nathalia is expected to remain above the minor flood level (1.50 m) for the next few days.


Updated community information: 

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent. More information on how to reduce your risk visit Better Health (Mosquitoes)

In flood-affected areas, there can be some cases of gastro (gastroenteritis, diarrhoea) causing people to get very sick. For information on how to prevent illness visit Better Health (Gastro)

Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould)

Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility.  Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases.

Flood waters may contain sewerage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home. Contact with sewerage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas.

The wet ground conditions have resulted in many trees falling without warning. 

If it gets windy, trees will become more unstable and deadly. Never park, take shelter or camp under a tree. 

Do not camp close to rivers or creeks.

Unexpected river rises are very likely after even small amounts of rainfall.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

In the VicEmergency App, add a watch zone for your campsite and regularly check emergency broadcasters via car radio if necessary. 

What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Donâ€™t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 11/11/2022 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.location: the Murray River downstream of Liparoo to Wentworth
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for the Murray River downstream of Liparoo to Wentworth

This Watch and Act message updates the Watch and Act flood warning issued yesterday afternoon. 

MAJOR FLOODING HIGHER THAN THE 1975 FLOOD POSSIBLE AT WAKOOL JUNCTION, BOUNDARY BEND, EUSTON, MILDURA, AND WENTWORTH
SWAN HILL PEAKED ON TUESDAY WITH MODERATE FLOODING

  • Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray and Edwards Rivers and their tributaries.
  • Increased rainfall is likely during tomorrow Thursday,  possibly 10-30 mm,  with another front bringing rain over the weekend that is forecast to affect the North Central and North East part of Victoria.
  • Ongoing releases from the Hume Dam combined with Kiewa River flows have caused moderate flooding along the Murray River at Albury, Corowa, Yarrawonga and Tocumwal.
  • Forecasts will be progressively refined once upstream flood peaks along the Murray River and its tributaries are observed.
  • Flood operations are being conducted by the Murray-Darling Basin Authority (MDBA) at Hume Dam to manage inflows from the upper Murray, Mitta Mitta River and other tributaries. MDBA are working closely with the Bureau and WaterNSW to plan release strategies.

  • At Boundary Bend and Wentworth Moderate flooding is currently occurring. 
  • The Murray River at Boundary Bend may exceed the major flood level (9.00 metres) around Saturday 12 November. The river level may reach near 9.10 metres around 15-17 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • At Euston Minor flooding is currently occurring and may exceed the moderate flood level (9.80 metres, 51.60 metres AHD) around 13-16 November. The river level may exceed the major flood level (10.30 metres, 52.10 metres AHD) around 16-18 November and reach around 10.40 metres (52.24 metres AHD) around 19-22 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible
  • The Murray River at Mildura Weir, Minor flooding is currently occurring and is likely to exceed the moderate flood level (37.50 metres AHD) around 21-25 November. The river level may exceed the major flood level (38.50 metres AHD) and may reach 38.60 metres AHD around the end of November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • At Echuca and Moama, river levels are slowly receding, with major flooding likely to continue until around Friday. 
  • At Torrumbarry, river levels are expected to remain steady due to continuing breakout flows, with major flooding forecast into mid November. Significant breakout flows from Torrumbarry have spilled into the Wakool River. These flows, combined with floodwaters from the Murray and Edward Rivers, have caused major flooding at Wakool Junction and may cause major flooding downstream at Boundary Bend, Euston, Mildura and Wentworth, with levels higher than the 1975 flood event.
  • At Barham, a major flood peak was observed around 26 October following a series of renewed rises. River levels are falling slowly, with major flooding likely to continue through to the end of the week. 
  • At Swan Hill the river level peaked on Tuesday with moderate flooding. Moderate flooding is occurring at Wentworth. The Murray River at Swan Hill peaked at 4.60 metres around midday Tuesday and is currently at 4.59 metres and falling slowly with near moderate flooding. The Murray River at Swan Hill may remain around the moderate flood level (4.60 m) through to the weekend.
  • At Wakool Junction, the Murray River  may reach near 12.00 metres around 15-17 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • At Wentworth, the Murray River  may exceed the major flood level (33.88 metres AHD) and reach 34.30 metres AHD around the first week of December, with major flooding. 
Along the Edward River
  • moderate flooding continues at Deniliquin, Stevens Weir and Moulamein. 
  • At Moulamein the river is peaking near 5.90 meters from the combined flows along the Edward River and Billabong Creek. Renewed rises are possible from mid to late November onwards.
  • Renewed rises are likely along the Edward River through mid to late November as upstream Murray River flows arrive.
  • At Deniliquin, renewed rises are occurring along the Edward River, where the river level may reach near 9.00 metres around 14-16 November, with moderate flooding.
  • At Stevens Weir Downstream is likely to reach around 6.50 metres around 16-18 November, with moderate flooding.

This message is for communities in Victoria. Flood impacts vary along the Murray River between NSW and Victoria. For information and warnings relevant to NSW, please check www.ses.nsw.gov.au. Always follow the instructions provided by your State's emergency services. 

 
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:

  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Be prepared to move vehicles, livestock and farming equipment to higher ground if still safe to do
  • If necessary, lift household or shed items (including farm chemicals) on top of tables, chairs, benches or up to high shelves. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never  play or swim in floodwater.
Watch the latest video Flood update
  • To watch today's Incident Controller update relating to Watch and Act warnings for some of the communities currently coming under flood threat to prepare to evacuate go to YouTube or click on this link  https://youtu.be/HFHknmpxMI8
  • To watch a YouTube video Sunday night's Community Meeting in Mildura, including Questions and Answers,  go to https://youtu.be/JbjNCvrBNvE
Attend one of the coming community information sessions or meetings:

  • Nichols Point Mon 14.11.22 NOTE TIME CHANGE drop in session 5pm-6 pm, Nichols Point Primary School 
  • Red Cliffs drop in session Tue 15.11.22 3pm-5pm, Red Cliffs Library
  • Note: more being planned across the municipality
Collect the latest Flood Information from Pick-up Points being set up (maps, newsletters, handouts etc) at:
  • Mildura City Heart Langtree mall
  • Mildura WAVES Visitor Information Centre
  • Mildura Library  
  • Mildura SMECC Sunraysia Mallee Ethnic Communities Council
  • Nangiloc Store 


If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for possibly a few weeks in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household and shed items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and shelves.
Impacts in your area:

  • Emergency services and Mildura Council are currently working to protect important community infrastructure, such as the Nangiloc Primary School, approved works at the Mildura Waste Water Treatment Plant.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Police doorknocking today indicates that Flooding above floor level of a single-story home and sheds or garages is likely to occur in some locations and access roads into some communities may be increasingly affected by slowly rising floodwater. Evacuation of some of these houses may be required.
  • The Murray River will be closed through to the South Australian Border to all non-emergency activities in the next few days. SES will update you when that happens via this warning. Fishing and boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • At Nangiloc, a Sandbag Collection point has been set up at the Recreation Reserve. The access to river water has also been cut, so the community can access water provided by council and a portaloo will be set up near the sandbag point at the recreation reserve as soon as possible.
  • Black water (a lack of oxygen and breaking down of leaves and plants) is starting to affect many areas including near Mildura. This kills fish and crayfish. Do not eat dead fish from the river.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds in many areas are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks. 
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services. 
Road closed? Signs or not.....If it's is flooded, forget it.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
For mental health information and support contact the below organisations: 
Lifeline on www.lifeline.org.au or phone 13 11 14. 
Beyond Blue on www.beyondblue.org.au or phone 1300 224 636. 
Kids Helpine on www.kidshelp.com.au or phone 1800 551 800. 
SANE Australia on www.sane.org or phone 1800 187 263.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Murray River downstream of Wakool Junction to Liparoo.
properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for the Murray River downstream of Wakool Junction to Liparoo.

Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray River and its tributaries. Water levels are expected to stay high for a few weeks, due to widespread rain over NSW and Victoria and saturated catchment soils. 

  • Major flooding is occurring at Wakool Junction. The Murray River at Wakool Junction may reach near 12.00 metres around 15 to 17 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • Moderate flooding is occurring at Boundary Bend. The Murray River at Boundary Bend may exceed the major flood level (9.00 metres) around Saturday 12 November. The river level may reach near 9.10 metres around 15 to 17 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • The Murray River at Euston may exceed the moderate flood level (9.80 metres, 51.60 metres AHD) around 13-16 November. The river level may exceed the major flood level (10.30 metres, 52.10 metres AHD) around 16 to 18 November and reach around 10.40 metres (52.24 metres AHD) around 19 to 22 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
Significant breakout flows from Torrumbarry have spilled into the Wakool River. These flows, combined with floodwaters from the Murray and Edward Rivers, have caused major flooding at Wakool Junction and may cause major flooding downstream at Boundary Bend, Euston (Robinvale), Mildura and Wentworth, with levels higher than the 1975 flood event. 

Forecasts will be progressively refined once the upstream flood peaks along the Murray River and its tributaries are observed.

Some properties in rural areas may be isolated due to standing water. Aircraft (including drones) are being used to determine the extent of water inundation across the area. Emergency services personnel are assessing impacts on affected properties caused by overtopping and levee breeches.

Emergency services are assessing and reinforcing existing levees as required, protecting isolated assets and providing relief to local communities and primary producers.  The evaluation of potential impacts on critical infrastructure and townships remains a focus.

The latest community newsletter dated Wednesday 9 November 2022 is available here: Community Newsletter.

Upcoming community drop in sessions for Thursday 10 November:

Robinvale
Outside Marciano's Cafe
11.30am to 1pm

Wemen
Wemen Store
2pm to 3.30pm

Community drop in sessions provide information to the community on forecast inundation mapping for each area and other important information to ensure the community can be prepared for potential floodwater impacts.

This message is for communities in Victoria. Flood impacts vary along the Murray River between NSW and Victoria. For information and warnings relevant to NSW, please check www.ses.nsw.gov.au. Always follow the instructions provided by your State's emergency services.   
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
Never allow children to play in or near floodwater! 
  • Flooded rivers and creeks can contain toxic chemicals such as petrol, oil, animal or human waste, pesticides and runoff from roads, paddocks, drains and even sewage overflows (poo and wee and anything else that is flushed down the toilet).
  • Raw sewage and floodwater can contain bacteria and viruses like E Coli, Giardia and Hepatitis A. Swallowing even a small amount of this can make your children sick. Open cuts, grazes and wounds can easily become infected.
  • Barbed wire, rubbish, branches, broken glass, metal fragments and other loose items can all find their way into floodwater. These objects can cause a child to get tangled or severely injured. They could lose their footing and strain a muscle, roll an ankle or they could fall and be knocked unconscious.   
Floodwater is dangerous. Stay safe - never enter floodwater. 

If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Support for flood impacted farmers and producers:
  • Farmers who require support to prepare for flooding, who have been impacted by floods and require assistance or have urgent animal welfare needs, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
  • For further information on managing crops and livestock after a flood, including budget feed plans, and other support and assistance, visit agriculture.vic.gov.au

Impacts in your area:

  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home may occur in some locations.
  • Levees may overtop in some areas.
  • High river levels may cause flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Some agricultural land may be vulnerable to flooding. Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Local roads may be closed. For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • An Emergency Warning - Not safe to return message is current for Kenley. 
  • The Murray River at Boundary Bend may exceed the major flood level around 12 November and peak around 15 to 17 November. Emergency services crews are undertaking pre-emptive levee construction and sandbagging at Tol Tol. 
  • The Murray River at Euston may exceed the major flood level around 19 to 22 November with further rises possible. 
  • The Murray River at Wemen is currently at 47.73m and rising. Levee construction and sandbagging is being carried out.
  • Drones are being used for aerial observation between Kenley and Robinvale
Murray River closure:  
  • The Murray River is closed to river craft downstream of Tocumwal Bridge to Robinvale. People and boats are prohibited from entering the river between these locations. 
  • Any person on the Murray between these points are to leave the river.  This declaration applies to all residents on both sides of the border.
  • Neither NSW or Victorian users are permitted on the river at this time.  
Snakes: 
  • There are a high number of snakes active in flooded areas.
  • Snakes may look for shelter and food in flooded areas. Be careful around houses, storage sheds and other buildings near floodwater.
  • Call DELWP on 136 186 for advice on snake controllers in your area. If someone is bitten, call 000 immediately. 
Mosquito alert 
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. 
  • For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes) 
Infectious diseases: 
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases. 
  •  There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness.  
  •  Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected. 
  •  Find out more, visit:  Better Health (Emergencies - floods) 
Mould: 
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell.  
  • For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home) 
Flood-affected septic systems: 
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include: 
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked 
  • Tanks and sumps 
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework 
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
Blackwater event:   
Significant rainfall and flooding can cause water quality issues like low-oxygen (hypoxic) blackwater and blue green algae. High levels of organic matter have been washed into waterways and, combined with warm weather, can cause oxygen levels in the water to drop. This can harm or cause the death of fish and crayfish. River managers and scientists monitor rivers for water quality issues and work to reduce the impacts of a blackwater event where they can. Low levels of dissolved oxygen are recorded at several locations across northern Victoria and in the Murray River. The scale of the current flooding means water quality will not improve quickly. Any fish death event in Victoria should be reported to the EPA by calling 1300 372 842. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

properties.text: WATCH & ACT - RIVERINE FLOOD - Avoid the Flooded Area Incident Location: Murray River downstream of Wakool Junction to Liparoo Issue Date: Wednesday 09 November 2022, 08:18 pm Next Update: Thursday 10 November 2022, 05:30 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/26489/moreinfo This Major Flood Warning is being issued for the Murray River downstream of Wakool Junction to Liparoo. Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray River and its tributaries. Water levels are expected to stay high for a few weeks, due to widespread rain over NSW and Victoria and saturated catchment soils. - Major flooding is occurring at Wakool Junction. The Murray River at Wakool Junction may reach near 12.00 metres around 15 to 17 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible. - Moderate flooding is occurring at Boundary Bend. The Murray River at Boundary Bend may exceed the major flood level (9.00 metres) around Saturday 12 November. The river level may reach near 9.10 metres around 15 to 17 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible. - The Murray River at Euston may exceed the moderate flood level (9.80 metres, 51.60 metres AHD) around 13-16 November. The river level may exceed the major flood level (10.30 metres, 52.10 metres AHD) around 16 to 18 November and reach around 10.40 metres (52.24 metres AHD) around 19 to 22 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible. Significant breakout flows from Torrumbarry have spilled into the Wakool River. These flows, combined with floodwaters from the Murray and Edward Rivers, have caused major flooding at Wakool Junction and may cause major flooding downstream at Boundary Bend, Euston (Robinvale), Mildura and Wentworth, with levels higher than the 1975 flood event. Forecasts will be progressively refined once the upstream flood peaks along the Murray River and its tributaries are observed. Some properties in rural areas may be isolated due to standing water. Aircraft (including drones) are being used to determine the extent of water inundation across the area. Emergency services personnel are assessing impacts on affected properties caused by overtopping and levee breeches. Emergency services are assessing and reinforcing existing levees as required, protecting isolated assets and providing relief to local communities and primary producers. The evaluation of potential impacts on critical infrastructure and townships remains a focus. The latest community newsletter dated Wednesday 9 November 2022 is available here: Community Newsletter. Upcoming community drop in sessions for Thursday 10 November: Robinvale Outside Marciano's Cafe 11.30am to 1pm Wemen Wemen Store 2pm to 3.30pm Community drop in sessions provide information to the community on forecast inundation mapping for each area and other important information to ensure the community can be prepared for potential floodwater impacts. This message is for communities in Victoria. Flood impacts vary along the Murray River between NSW and Victoria. For information and warnings relevant to NSW, please check www.ses.nsw.gov.au. Always follow the instructions provided by your State's emergency services. Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa.

This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 1.08 pm Tuesday 08/11/2022.

MINOR FLOODING SLOWLY EASING AT KIALLA WEST

Minor flooding is slowly easing at Kialla West.

Showers and thunderstorms are forecast for Thursday and Friday and renewed rises are possible from late Thursday. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.

Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa.

The Seven Creeks at Kialla West is currently at 4.50 metres and falling very slowly, with minor flooding. The Seven Creeks at Kialla West is likely to fall below the minor flood level (4.50 m) late Wednesday.


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/11/2022 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.  
Community Information

Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould)

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent. More information on how to reduce your risk Visit Better Health (Mosquitoes) 

Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility.  Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases. 

For information on how to prevent gastro visit Better Health (Gastro)

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Campaspe River downstream of Rochester.

  • Minor flooding is continuing along the Campaspe River at Echuca.
  • Showers and thunderstorms are forecast for Thursday and Friday and renewed rises are possible from Saturday. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary. 
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Campaspe River downstream of Rochester. 
  • The Campaspe River at Echuca is currently at 94.11 m AHD (Australian Height Datum) and steady, with minor flooding. The river is expected to remain above the minor flood level (92.80 m AHD) for the remainder of Wednesday through to Friday.
  • Further rises are possible from Saturday based on forecast rainfall and also due to the elevated water levels in the Murray River at Echuca.
  • This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued Monday 7 November at 12.35pm.
The latest community newsletter from Monday 7th November is available here: Community Newsletter Monday 7th November - Campaspe/Murray

Parts of Echuca and Echuca Village remain flooded, avoid flooded areas.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Review your emergency plan and check your emergency kit is fully stocked, if you have one.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Mosquito alert:
With the recent floods in many areas across Victoria, the risk of mosquito breeding is high. Learn more about how to protect yourself and your family at https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/protect-yourself-mosquito-borne-disease.  

What you can do: 
  • Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing.
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin.
  • Use mosquito nets or insect screens.
  • Limit activity outdoors and move indoors if possible.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Donâ€™t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River to Tocumwal.

This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued at 4.55
Tuesday 08/11/2022.

Releases from the Hume Dam combined with Kiewa River flows have caused moderate flooding along the Murray River at Albury, Corowa, Yarrawonga and Tocumwal.
 
Flood operations are being conducted by the Murray-Darling Basin Authority (MDBA) at Hume Dam to manage inflows from the upper Murray, Mitta Mitta River and other tributaries. MDBA are working closely with the Bureau and WaterNSW to plan release strategies.

Murray River downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal:

Moderate flooding is occurring at Albury, Corowa, Yarrawonga and Tocumwal.

The Murray River at Albury peaked at 5.39 metres around 03:00 pm Wednesday 02 November and is currently at 5.25 metres and slowly falling, with moderate flooding. Subject to increased spills from the Hume Dam, renewed river level rises are possible at Albury from Wednesday evening onwards.

The Murray River at Corowa peaked at 7.55 metres around 04:00 pm Saturday 05 November and is currently at 7.43 metres and and slowly falling, with moderate flooding.

The Murray River at Yarrawonga Downstream peaked at 7.13 metres around 11:45 am Saturday 05 November and is currently at 6.88 metres and falling, with moderate flooding. The river level at Yarrawonga Downstream may remain around 7.00 metres for the next few days.

The Murray River at Tocumwal peaked at 6.95 metres around 02:45 pm Monday 07 November and is currently at 6.85 metres and falling, with moderate flooding. The river level at Tocumwal is likely to remain around 6.90 metres through to Wednesday, with moderate flooding.

This message is for communities in Victoria. Flood impacts vary along the Murray River between NSW and Victoria. For information and warnings relevant to NSW, please check www.ses.nsw.gov.au. Always follow the instructions provided by your State's emergency services.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Donâ€™t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.

Community Information

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent for more information visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes)

For information about gastro prevention, visit: Better Health (Gastro)

Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home.  Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

WATCH & ACT - RIVERINE FLOOD - Avoid the Flooded Area 
Incident Location: Murray River to Tocumwal
Issue Date: Wednesday 09 November 2022, 07:14 pm
Next Update: Thursday 10 November 2022, 05:30 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/26488/moreinfo

This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River to Tocumwal.

This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued at 4.55
Tuesday 08/11/2022.

Releases from the Hume Dam combined with Kiewa River flows have caused moderate flooding along the Murray River at Albury, Corowa, Yarrawonga and Tocumwal. 
 
Flood operations are being conducted by the Murray-Darling Basin Authority (MDBA) at Hume Dam to manage inflows from the upper Murray, Mitta Mitta River and other tributaries. MDBA are working closely with the Bureau and WaterNSW to plan release strategies. 

Murray River downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal:

Moderate flooding is occurring at Albury, Corowa, Yarrawonga and Tocumwal.

The Murray River at Albury peaked at 5.39 metres around 03:00 pm Wednesday 02 November and is currently at 5.25 metres and slowly falling, with moderate flooding. Subject to increased spills from the Hume Dam, renewed river level rises are possible at Albury from Wednesday evening onwards.

The Murray River at Corowa peaked at 7.55 metres around 04:00 pm Saturday 05 November and is currently at 7.43 metres and and slowly falling, with moderate flooding.

The Murray River at Yarrawonga Downstream peaked at 7.13 metres around 11:45 am Saturday 05 November and is currently at 6.88 metres and falling, with moderate flooding. The river level at Yarrawonga Downstream may remain around 7.00 metres for the next few days.

The Murray River at Tocumwal peaked at 6.95 metres around 02:45 pm Monday 07 November and is currently at 6.85 metres and falling, with moderate flooding. The river level at Tocumwal is likely to remain around 6.90 metres through to Wednesday, with moderate flooding. 

This message is for communities in Victoria. Flood impacts vary along the Murray River between NSW and Victoria. For information and warnings relevant to NSW, please check www.ses.nsw.gov.au. Always follow the instructions provided by your State's emergency services. 

Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Echuca and Echuca Village.
  •  This Watch and Act message replaces the Emergency Warning issued Tuesday 8 November at 4:59pm. 
  • Showers and thunderstorms are forecast for Thursday and Friday and renewed river level rises are possible later this week. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.
  • Dangerous flood water and standing water remains in Echuca, continue to avoid flooded areas.
  • For people who have already evacuated some areas remain flooded it still may not be safe to return.
MURRAY RIVER
  • Major flooding is occurring at Echuca.
  • Along the Murray River at Echuca, river levels are slowly receding, with major flooding likely to continue until around Friday.
  • The Murray River at Echuca peaked at 94.98 metres AHD on Wednesday 26 October and is currently at 94.47 metres AHD and falling slowly, with major flooding. The river level at Echuca is likely to remain above the major flood level (94.40 metres) through to Friday.
CAMPASPE RIVER
  • Minor flooding is continuing along the Campaspe River at Echuca.
  • The Campaspe River at Echuca is currently at 94.11 m AHD (Australian Height Datum) and steady, with minor flooding. 
  • The river is expected to remain above the minor flood level (92.80 m AHD) for the remainder of Wednesday through to Friday. 
  • Further rises are possible from Saturday based on forecast rainfall and also due to the elevated water levels in the Murray River at Echuca.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • If you have not already evacuated be aware that you may be isolated by floodwater for a significant amount of time.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters, monitoring warnings, weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Avoid being on or near the levee in Echuca township to reduce the risk of damage to the levee.
  • To prevent the sewer network being overwhelmed all Echuca residents should minimise use of anything that produces waste water, including toilets, showers, baths, dishwashers and washing machines.
  • The Echuca Emergency Relief Centre (Echuca South Basketball Stadium located at 244 High Street, Echuca) can be accessed between 9:00am - 5:00pm.

If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.

If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for several weeks in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services. 
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Donâ€™t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
  • Drinking water in Echuca is safe for all drinking, bathing and cleaning purposes.
  • Further Information about response and recovery can be obtained from the Community Newsletter available here: Community Newsletter        
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act is being issued for Loddon River downstream of Kerang.

River levels are elevated along the Loddon River downstream of Kerang.

  • Some breeches and overtopping of levees have occurred over the past week leading to impacts on buildings, farmland and roads in the Murrabit West and Benjeroop and into areas north of Kerang. 
  • High water levels continue to move downstream with impacts on some properties and surrounding agricultural land.  
  • There is currently no access for 4WD vehicles between Murrabit West and Benjeroop due to water inundation along Murrabit West Road. 
  • Emergency Services are actively patrolling and monitoring the integrity of levees, roads and bridges while continuing work to reinforce control lines and sandbagging.
Showers and thunderstorms are forecast for Thursday and Friday and renewed river level rises are possible. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.

The latest community newsletter from Saturday 5 November is available here: Community Newsletter
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:
  • Drive slowly, obey all roadblocks and never drive through floodwaters. Check the VicTraffic website for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Stay away from damaged and flooded buildings, fallen or damaged trees and powerlines, and damaged roads until authorities advise they are safe.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Contact Gannawarra Shire Council or go to https://www.emergency.vic.gov.au/relief/#relief_assistance for relief and recovery information.
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.
  • Protect your health and safety when cleaning. Wear strong boots, gloves and protective clothing and wash your hands and clothes regularly.
  • If you have lost power for a prolonged time due to flooding, you should not consume food from your fridge or freezer. Throw out food that has touched floodwater or has an unusual smell, colour or texture, do not taste or cook it.
  • Electricity: Only turn on power at the mains if water has not entered your property. Have wiring and appliances tested and tagged before use.
  • Gas: If your home has been impacted by floodwater, do not attempt to turn the gas supply back on. Gas lines may contain water and must be checked by the distribution company. Contact details can be found on the top right of your gas bill.
Never allow children to play in or near floodwater! 
  • Flooded rivers and creeks can contain toxic chemicals such as petrol, oil, animal or human waste, pesticides and runoff from roads, paddocks, drains and even sewage overflows (poo and wee and anything else that is flushed down the toilet).
  • Raw sewage and floodwater can contain bacteria and viruses like E Coli, Giardia and Hepatitis A. Swallowing even a small amount of this can make your children sick. Open cuts, grazes and wounds can easily become infected.
  • Barbed wire, rubbish, branches, broken glass, metal fragments and other loose items can all find their way into floodwater. These objects can cause a child to get tangled or severely injured. They could lose their footing and strain a muscle, roll an ankle or they could fall and be knocked unconscious.
Floodwater is dangerous. Stay safe - never enter floodwater.

Support for flood impacted farmers and producers:
  • Farmers who require support to prepare for flooding, who have been impacted by floods and require assistance or have urgent animal welfare needs, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
  • For further information on managing crops and livestock after a flood, budget feed plans, and other support and assistance, visit agriculture.vic.gov.au
Impacts in your area:
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Parts of the Murray Valley Highway is impacted by floodwater.
  • Other roads and bridges may be impacted by floodwater.
Exclusion zones:
Exclusion zones are in place due to hazardous waterways and debris flow. It is expected that many of these will remain in place until late November. These include:
  • Lake Charm
  • Kangaroo Lake
  • Lake Meran
  • All waters of Gunbower Creek that are within the Shire of Gannawarra.
Further information can be found at: https://transportsafety.vic.gov.au/maritime-safety/newsroom.

Snakes: 
  • There are a high number of snakes active in flooded areas.
  • Snakes may look for shelter and food in flooded areas. Be careful around houses, storage sheds and other buildings near floodwater.
  • Call DELWP on 136 186 for advice on snake controllers in your area. 
  • If someone is bitten, call 000 immediately
Mosquito alert: 
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. 
  • For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes) 
Infectious diseases: 
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases. 
  • There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness.  
  • Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected. 
  • Find out more:  Better Health (Emergencies - floods) 
Mould: 
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. 
  • When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell.  
  •  For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home) 
Flood-affected septic systems: 
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include: 
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked 
  • Tanks and sumps 
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework 
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 11/11/2022 02:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
